name: Roo.EventManager
desc:
Registers event handlers that want to receive a normalized EventObject instead of the standard browser event and provides 
several useful events directly.
See {@link Roo.EventObject} for more details on normalized event objects.

methods.name: addListener
methods.desc: Appends an event handler to an element (shorthand for addListener)

params.name: element
params.desc: The html element or id to assign the

params.name: eventName
params.desc: The type of event to listen for

params.name: handler
params.desc: The method the event invokes

params.name: scope
params.desc:
(optional) The scope in which to execute the handler
function. The handler function's "this" context.

params.name: options
params.desc:
(optional) An object containing handler configuration properties. This may contain any of the following properties:
  • scope {Object} The scope in which to execute the handler function. The handler function's "this" context.
  • delegate {String} A simple selector to filter the target or look for a descendant of the target
  • stopEvent {Boolean} True to stop the event. That is stop propagation, and prevent the default action.
  • preventDefault {Boolean} True to prevent the default action
  • stopPropagation {Boolean} True to prevent event propagation
  • normalized {Boolean} False to pass a browser event to the handler function instead of an Roo.EventObject
  • delay {Number} The number of milliseconds to delay the invocation of the handler after te event fires.
  • single {Boolean} True to add a handler to handle just the next firing of the event, and then remove itself.
  • buffer {Number} Causes the handler to be scheduled to run in an {@link Roo.util.DelayedTask} delayed by the specified number of milliseconds. If the event fires again within that time, the original handler is not invoked, but the new handler is scheduled in its place.

Combining Options
Using the options argument, it is possible to combine different types of listeners:

A normalized, delayed, one-time listener that auto stops the event and passes a custom argument (forumId)

Code:

el.on('click', this.onClick, this, {
    single: true,
    delay: 100,
    stopEvent : true,
    forumId: 4
});

Attaching multiple handlers in 1 call
The method also allows for a single argument to be passed which is a config object containing properties which specify multiple handlers.

Code:


el.on({
    'click' : {
        fn: this.onClick
        scope: this,
        delay: 100
    },
    'mouseover' : {
        fn: this.onMouseOver
        scope: this
    },
    'mouseout' : {
        fn: this.onMouseOut
        scope: this
    }
});

Or a shorthand syntax:
Code:


el.on({
    'click' : this.onClick,
    'mouseover' : this.onMouseOver,
    'mouseout' : this.onMouseOut
    scope: this
});

methods.name: onDocumentReady
methods.desc:
Fires when the document is ready (before onload and before images are loaded). Can be 
accessed shorthanded Roo.onReady().

params.name: fn
params.desc: The method the event invokes

params.name: scope
params.desc: An  object that becomes the scope of the handler

methods.name: onTextResize
methods.desc: Fires when the user changes the active text size. Handler gets called with 2 params, the old size and the new size.

params.name: fn
params.desc: The method the event invokes

params.name: scope
params.desc: An object that becomes the scope of the handler

methods.name: removeResizeListener
methods.desc: Removes the passed window resize listener.

params.name: fn
params.desc: The method the event invokes

params.name: scope
params.desc: The scope of handler

methods.name: onWindowResize
methods.desc: Fires when the window is resized and provides resize event buffering (50 milliseconds), passes new viewport width and height to handlers.

params.name: fn
params.desc: The method the event invokes

params.name: scope
params.desc: An object that becomes the scope of the handler

methods.name: wrap
methods.desc:
This is no longer needed and is deprecated. Places a simple wrapper around an event handler to override the browser event
object with a Roo.EventObject

params.name: fn
params.desc: The method the event invokes

params.name: scope
params.desc: An object that becomes the scope of the handler

params.name: override
params.desc:
If true, the obj passed in becomes
                            the execution scope of the listener

params.name: element
params.desc:
The id or html element to remove the 
                            event from

params.name: eventName
params.desc: The type of event

returns.desc: True if a listener was actually removed
